text: when we don't play by the rules there
are penalties to pay and it's the same
for countries the US has placed
penalties on Iran since the Revolution
back in 1979 they say these sanctions
are aimed at the government not the
people using these five things I'm going
to show you how sanctions are affecting
Iranians day to day lives
medicine has become harder and more
expensive to get hold of sanctions are
not supposed to apply to medical
supplies but they do indirectly some
drug suppliers are now refusing to sell
to Iran to avoid falling foul of the US
this has led to shortages pushing
thousands of lives at risk there are
people suffering from cancer epilepsy or
hemophilia who are struggling to get
treatment and Iran can't even make its
own versions of some of these drugs
because it's difficult to import the
essential ingredients Washington on the
other hand says corruption and
mismanagement are to blame
[Music]
they're so old they still have ashtrays
in the arm rests some Iranians call them
flying coffins and no wonder in the past
25 years more than 2,000 people have
died in air crashes involving Iranian
planes for 40 years Airlines in Iran
have struggled to update and maintain
their fleets because trade sanctions
were imposed in 1979 after a hostage
crisis in the US Embassy in Tehran Iran
was later hit by even more sanctions
over its nuclear program but under an
international deal in 2015 they agreed
to limit their nuclear activities it
looked like boeing and airbus were going
to sell iran almost 200 new planes but
three years later only a handful of
planes were delivered before President
Trump abandoned the deal and revoked the
export licenses so much for safe travels
[Music]
Iran is dealing with ink shortages and
the price of imported paper has more
than tripled since the u.s. pulled out
of the nuclear deal not good news for
publishers of newspapers and books many
well-established papers have now simply
become several pages lighter with
existing heavy restrictions on press
freedom in Iran journalists and
publishers say this situation will make
it even harder to hold the government to
account this a kilo of red meat has
become a luxury in Iran it used to cost
10 US dollars before the new sanctions
kicked in now it's more than double that
price sanctions on Iranian banks have
made it hard to import food so many
people have been forced to simply cut
meat from their diet nearly a quarter of
all restaurants in Tehran have shut down
and rationing has been reintroduced for
the first time since the iran-iraq war
in the 80s Iranians like everyone else
use their smartphones to book taxis or
food deliveries but many international
tech companies like uber don't operate
in Iran so Iranian developers created
their own versions like this one snap
but the problem is Iran's 9 million
iPhone users can't download these apps
from the App Store because under the US
sanctions regulations the app store
cannot host distribute or do business
with apps or developers connected to
certain US embargoed countries the
internet in Iran is already strictly
regulated and censored so young Iranian
developers are feeling the squeeze from
both inside and outside the country
whilst both Tehran and Washington blame
each other for the sanctions
try convincing ordinary Iranians that
these sanctions are not actually aimed
at them
